instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1370: What is A1370? A1370 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2393, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2796, 820-3024..
definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no Power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> -<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B, that has green light, but no fan spin and no power. It consumes 10mA on bench PSU.

Even though I get a green light, on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, I only get 0.500V. 

Diode reading on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.485

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

Already tried a new DC in board, with same result.

Can you help?
